sn35.116:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.116:0.3.eng: Traveling to the End of the World

sn35.116:1.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.
sn35.116:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
sn35.116:1.1.comm: The “end of the world” is taught to brahmin cosmologists at AN 9.38, and illustrated with the parable of Rohitassa at SN 2.26 = AN 4.45. | I use both “world” and “cosmos” for loka. As this discourse shows, the exact meaning is highly mutable and context-specific.

sn35.116:1.2.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmī”ti.
sn35.116:1.2.eng: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.”

sn35.116:1.3.pli: Idaṃ vatvā bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
sn35.116:1.3.eng: When he had spoken, the Blessed One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

sn35.116:1.4.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:
sn35.116:1.4.eng: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,

sn35.116:1.5.pli: “idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
sn35.116:1.5.eng: “The Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. …

sn35.116:1.6.pli: ‘“nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyan”ti vadāmi.

sn35.116:1.7.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmī’ti.

sn35.116:1.8.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā”ti?
sn35.116:1.8.eng: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha?”

sn35.116:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
sn35.116:2.2.eng: “This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

sn35.116:2.3.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
sn35.116:2.3.eng: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

sn35.116:2.4.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā”ti.
sn35.116:2.4.eng: Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.”

sn35.116:3.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn35.116:3.1.eng: Then those mendicants went to Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.

sn35.116:3.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn35.116:3.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said,

sn35.116:4.1.pli: “Idaṃ kho no, āvuso ānanda, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

sn35.116:4.2.pli: ‘nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.

sn35.116:4.3.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmī’ti.

sn35.116:4.4.pli: Tesaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:

sn35.116:4.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho—

sn35.116:4.6.pli: nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.

sn35.116:4.7.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmīti.

sn35.116:4.8.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

sn35.116:4.10.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho, āvuso, āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

sn35.116:4.11.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

sn35.116:4.12.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā’ti.

sn35.116:5.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva, mūlaṃ atikkammeva, khandhaṃ sākhāpalāse sāraṃ pariyesitabbaṃ maññeyya;
sn35.116:5.1.eng: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves.

sn35.116:5.2.pli: evaṃ sampadamidaṃ āyasmantānaṃ satthari sammukhībhūte taṃ bhagavantaṃ atisitvā amhe etamatthaṃ paṭipucchitabbaṃ maññatha.
sn35.116:5.2.eng: Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you bypassed him, imagining that you should ask me about this matter.

sn35.116:5.3.pli: So hāvuso, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passati—
sn35.116:5.3.eng: For he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

sn35.116:5.4.pli: cakkhubhūto, ñāṇabhūto, dhammabhūto, brahmabhūto, vattā, pavattā, atthassa ninnetā, amatassa dātā, dhammassāmī, tathāgato.

sn35.116:5.5.pli: So ceva panetassa kālo ahosi yaṃ bhagavantaṃyeva etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha.
sn35.116:5.5.eng: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.

sn35.116:5.6.pli: Yathā vo bhagavā byākareyya tathā vo dhāreyyāthā”ti.
sn35.116:5.6.eng: You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

sn35.116:6.1.pli: “Addhāvuso ānanda, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passati—
sn35.116:6.1.eng: “Certainly he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

sn35.116:6.2.pli: cakkhubhūto, ñāṇabhūto, dhammabhūto, brahmabhūto, vattā, pavattā, atthassa ninnetā, amatassa dātā, dhammassāmī, tathāgato.

sn35.116:6.3.pli: So ceva panetassa kālo ahosi yaṃ bhagavantaṃyeva etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāma.
sn35.116:6.3.eng: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.

sn35.116:6.4.pli: Yathā no bhagavā byākareyya tathā naṃ dhāreyyāma.
sn35.116:6.4.eng: We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.

sn35.116:6.5.pli: Api cāyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
sn35.116:6.5.eng: Still, Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

sn35.116:6.6.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
sn35.116:6.6.eng: You are capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

sn35.116:6.7.eng: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

sn35.116:7.1.eng: “Then listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn35.116:7.2.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṃ.

sn35.116:8.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho vo, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
sn35.116:8.1.eng: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

sn35.116:8.2.pli: ‘nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.
sn35.116:8.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.

sn35.116:8.3.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmī’ti,
sn35.116:8.3.eng: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’

sn35.116:8.4.pli: imassa khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
sn35.116:8.4.eng: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary recital.

sn35.116:8.5.pli: Yena kho, āvuso, lokasmiṃ lokasaññī hoti lokamānī—
sn35.116:8.5.eng: Whatever in the world through which you perceive the world and conceive the world

sn35.116:8.6.eng: is called the world in the training of the Noble One.

sn35.116:8.7.pli: Kena cāvuso, lokasmiṃ lokasaññī hoti lokamānī?
sn35.116:8.7.eng: And through what in the world do you perceive the world and conceive the world?

sn35.116:8.8.pli: Cakkhunā kho, āvuso, lokasmiṃ lokasaññī hoti lokamānī.
sn35.116:8.8.eng: Through the eye in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.

sn35.116:8.11.pli: jivhāya kho, āvuso, lokasmiṃ lokasaññī hoti lokamānī.

sn35.116:8.13.pli: manena kho, āvuso, lokasmiṃ lokasaññī hoti lokamānī.
sn35.116:8.13.eng: mind in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.

sn35.116:8.14.pli: Yena kho, āvuso, lokasmiṃ lokasaññī hoti lokamānī—
sn35.116:8.14.eng: Whatever in the world through which you perceive the world and conceive the world

sn35.116:8.15.eng: is called the world in the training of the Noble One.

sn35.116:8.16.pli: Yaṃ kho vo, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
sn35.116:8.16.eng: When the Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

sn35.116:8.17.pli: ‘nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.
sn35.116:8.17.eng: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.

sn35.116:8.18.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmī’ti,
sn35.116:8.18.eng: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’

sn35.116:8.19.pli: imassa khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
sn35.116:8.19.eng: That is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.

sn35.116:8.20.pli: Ākaṅkhamānā ca pana tumhe āyasmanto bhagavantaṃyeva upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha.
sn35.116:8.20.eng: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.

sn35.116:8.21.pli: Yathā vo bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
sn35.116:8.21.eng: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

sn35.116:9.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn35.116:9.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn35.116:10.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho no, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

sn35.116:10.2.pli: ‘nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.

sn35.116:10.3.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmī’ti.

sn35.116:10.4.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:

sn35.116:10.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho—

sn35.116:10.6.pli: nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ, daṭṭheyyaṃ, patteyyanti vadāmi.

sn35.116:10.7.pli: Na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmīti.

sn35.116:10.8.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

sn35.116:10.10.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

sn35.116:10.11.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

sn35.116:10.12.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā’ti.

sn35.116:10.13.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipucchimha.

sn35.116:10.14.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, āyasmatā ānandena imehi ākārehi imehi padehi imehi byañjanehi attho vibhatto”ti.
sn35.116:10.14.eng: Then they said, “And Ānanda explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

sn35.116:11.1.eng: “Mendicants, Ānanda is astute, he has great wisdom.

sn35.116:11.2.pli: Mañcepi tumhe, bhikkhave, etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha, ahampi taṃ evamevaṃ byākareyyaṃ yathā taṃ ānandena byākataṃ.
sn35.116:11.2.eng: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Ānanda.

sn35.116:11.3.pli: Eso cevetassa attho, evañca naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
sn35.116:11.3.eng: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

sn35.117:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.117:1.1.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn35.117:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

sn35.117:1.2.pli: ‘yeme pañca kāmaguṇā cetaso samphuṭṭhapubbā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā, tatra me cittaṃ bahulaṃ gacchamānaṃ gaccheyya paccuppannesu vā appaṃ vā anāgatesu’.
sn35.117:1.2.eng: ‘My mind might often stray towards the five kinds of sensual stimulation that I formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished—or to those in the present, or in the future a little.’
sn35.117:1.2.comm: This phrasing is unique, suggesting that worrying about the future “a little” was a particular scenario encountered by the Bodhisatta.

sn35.117:1.4.pli: ‘yeme pañca kāmaguṇā cetaso samphuṭṭhapubbā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā, tatra me attarūpena appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo’.
sn35.117:1.4.eng: ‘In my own way I should practice diligence, mindfulness, and protecting the mind regarding the five kinds of sensual stimulation that I formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished.’
sn35.117:1.4.comm: Attarūpa (“in my own way”) is also at AN 4.117:1.1 and DN 27:3.3. Commentary glosses, “in conformity with one’s own nature”, with the secondary sense, “for one’s own benefit”. | Compare attakāmarūpa at MN 31:3.5.

sn35.117:1.5.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, tumhākampi ye te pañca kāmaguṇā cetaso samphuṭṭhapubbā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā, tatra vo cittaṃ bahulaṃ gacchamānaṃ gaccheyya paccuppannesu vā appaṃ vā anāgatesu.
sn35.117:1.5.eng: So, mendicants, your minds might also often stray towards the five kinds of sensual stimulation that you formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished—or to those in the present, or in the future a little.

sn35.117:1.6.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, tumhākampi ye te pañca kāmaguṇā cetaso samphuṭṭhapubbā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā, tatra vo attarūpehi appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo.
sn35.117:1.6.eng: So in your own way you should practice diligence, mindfulness, and protecting the mind regarding the five kinds of sensual stimulation that you formerly experienced—which have passed, ceased, and perished.

sn35.117:1.7.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…
sn35.117:1.7.eng: So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away.
sn35.117:1.7.comm: The “dimension” (āyatana) is Nibbana. | This passage shares with MN 105:11.2 and Snp 5.8:6.7 the unusual form se, which here is the singular “that”. | For the concluding verb, accept the variant virajjati from PTS and BJT.

sn35.117:1.8.pli: yattha jivhā ca nirujjhati, rasasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…
sn35.117:1.8.eng: You should understand that dimension where the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.117:1.9.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe”ti.
sn35.117:1.9.eng: mind ceases and perception of ideas fades away.”

sn35.117:1.10.pli: Idaṃ vatvā bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
sn35.117:1.10.eng: When he had spoken, the Blessed One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

sn35.117:2.1.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:
sn35.117:2.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,

sn35.117:2.2.pli: “idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
sn35.117:2.2.eng: “The Buddha gave this brief summary, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. …

sn35.117:2.3.pli: ‘tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:2.4.pli: yattha jivhā ca nirujjhati, rasasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:2.5.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe’ti.

sn35.117:2.6.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā”ti?
sn35.117:2.6.eng: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?”

sn35.117:3.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
sn35.117:3.2.eng: “This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

sn35.117:3.3.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
sn35.117:3.3.eng: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha.

sn35.117:3.4.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā”ti.
sn35.117:3.4.eng: Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.”

sn35.117:4.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn35.117:4.1.eng: Then those mendicants went to Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn35.117:4.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn35.117:4.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said,

sn35.117:5.1.pli: “Idaṃ kho no, āvuso ānanda, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

sn35.117:5.2.pli: ‘tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:5.3.pli: yattha jivhā ca nirujjhati, rasasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:5.4.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe’ti.

sn35.117:5.5.pli: Tesaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:

sn35.117:5.6.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

sn35.117:5.7.pli: “tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:5.8.pli: yattha jivhā ca nirujjhati, rasasaññā ca nirujjhati se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:5.9.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe”ti.

sn35.117:5.10.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

sn35.117:5.12.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

sn35.117:5.13.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

sn35.117:5.14.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā’ti.

sn35.117:6.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa …pe…
sn35.117:6.1.eng: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. …”

sn35.117:6.2.eng: “Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

sn35.117:7.1.eng: “Then listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn35.117:7.2.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṃ.

sn35.117:8.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho vo, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
sn35.117:8.1.eng: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief summary, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

sn35.117:8.2.pli: ‘tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…
sn35.117:8.2.eng: ‘So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.117:8.3.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe’ti.
sn35.117:8.3.eng: mind ceases and perception of ideas fades away.’

sn35.117:8.4.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
sn35.117:8.4.eng: And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.

sn35.117:8.5.pli: Saḷāyatananirodhaṃ no etaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
sn35.117:8.5.eng: The Buddha was referring to the cessation of the six sense fields when he said:
sn35.117:8.5.comm: Concern for the past, present, and future is connected with experience—recalling it, enjoying it, or longing for it. One desires the future so that one’s senses can continue to enjoy pleasures. A perfected one no longer generates senses to sate their desires.

sn35.117:8.6.pli: ‘tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe, yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…
sn35.117:8.6.eng: ‘So you should understand that dimension where the eye ceases and perception of sights fades away. You should understand that dimension where the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.117:8.7.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe’ti.
sn35.117:8.7.eng: mind ceases and perception of ideas fades away.’

sn35.117:8.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
sn35.117:8.8.eng: The Buddha gave this brief summary, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.

sn35.117:8.9.pli: ‘tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:8.10.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe’ti.

sn35.117:8.11.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
sn35.117:8.11.eng: And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.

sn35.117:8.12.pli: Ākaṅkhamānā ca pana tumhe āyasmanto bhagavantaṃyeva upasaṅkamatha;
sn35.117:8.12.eng: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.

sn35.117:8.14.pli: Yathā vo bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
sn35.117:8.14.eng: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

sn35.117:9.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn35.117:9.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn35.117:10.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho no, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

sn35.117:10.2.pli: ‘tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:10.3.pli: yattha jivhā ca nirujjhati, rasasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:10.4.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe’ti, tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:

sn35.117:10.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

sn35.117:10.6.pli: “tasmātiha, bhikkhave, se āyatane veditabbe yattha cakkhu ca nirujjhati, rūpasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe …pe…

sn35.117:10.7.pli: yattha mano ca nirujjhati, dhammasaññā ca nirujjhati, se āyatane veditabbe”ti.

sn35.117:10.8.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

sn35.117:10.10.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito, sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

sn35.117:10.11.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

sn35.117:10.12.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāmā’ti.

sn35.117:10.13.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipucchimha.

sn35.117:10.14.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, āyasmatā ānandena imehi ākārehi, imehi padehi, imehi byañjanehi attho vibhatto”ti.
sn35.117:10.14.eng: Then they said, “And Ānanda explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

sn35.117:11.1.eng: “Mendicants, Ānanda is astute, he has great wisdom.

sn35.117:11.2.pli: Mañcepi tumhe, bhikkhave, etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha, ahampi taṃ evamevaṃ byākareyyaṃ yathā taṃ ānandena byākataṃ.
sn35.117:11.2.eng: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Ānanda.

sn35.117:11.3.pli: Eso cevetassa attho. Evañca naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
sn35.117:11.3.eng: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

sn35.118:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.118:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn35.118:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn35.118:1.1.comm: A long discourse of this name is at DN 21; see too the next discourse.

sn35.118:1.2.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.118:1.2.eng: And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

sn35.118:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti?
sn35.118:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life?

sn35.118:1.4.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti?
sn35.118:1.4.eng: What is the cause, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life?”

sn35.118:2.1.pli: “Santi kho, devānaminda, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.118:2.1.eng: “Lord of gods, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.118:2.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.118:2.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.118:2.3.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.118:2.3.eng: their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.118:2.4.eng: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.

sn35.118:3.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.118:3.2.pli: santi kho, devānaminda, manoviññeyyā dhammā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.118:3.2.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.118:3.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.118:3.3.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.118:3.4.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.118:3.4.eng: their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.118:3.5.eng: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.

sn35.118:3.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, devānaminda, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti.
sn35.118:3.6.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life.

sn35.118:4.1.pli: Santi ca kho, devānaminda, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.118:4.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.118:4.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.118:4.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.118:4.3.pli: Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato na tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti, na tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.118:4.3.eng: their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.118:4.4.eng: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.

sn35.118:5.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.118:5.2.pli: santi kho, devānaminda, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.118:5.2.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.118:5.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.118:5.3.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.118:5.4.pli: Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato na tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti na tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.118:5.4.eng: their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.118:5.5.eng: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.

sn35.118:5.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, devānaminda, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti.
sn35.118:5.6.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life.”

sn35.119:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.119:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn35.119:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn35.119:1.1.comm: For Pañcasikha, see DN 21 and notes there. This question  is uncharacteristic of the sensualist Pañcasikha, and it’s likely this discourse is an artificial construct, suggested by the fact that the previous discourse is “The Question of Sakka”.

sn35.119:1.2.pli: Atha kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.119:1.2.eng: And then the centaur Pañcasikha went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

sn35.119:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti?
sn35.119:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life?

sn35.119:1.4.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti?
sn35.119:1.4.eng: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life?”

sn35.119:1.5.eng: “Pañcasikha, there are sights known by the eye …

sn35.119:1.6.pli: santi kho, pañcasikha, manoviññeyyā dhammā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.119:1.6.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.119:1.7.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.119:1.7.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.119:1.8.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.119:1.8.eng: their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.119:1.9.eng: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.

sn35.119:1.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho, pañcasikha, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme no parinibbāyanti.
sn35.119:1.10.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life.

sn35.119:2.1.pli: Santi ca kho, pañcasikha, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā …pe…
sn35.119:2.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye …

sn35.119:2.2.pli: santi kho, pañcasikha, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.119:2.2.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.119:2.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati, tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato na tannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ hoti, na tadupādānaṃ.
sn35.119:2.3.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.

sn35.119:2.4.eng: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.

sn35.119:2.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, pañcasikha, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti.
sn35.119:2.5.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life.”

sn35.12:0.3.eng: The Exterior as Not-Self in the Three Times

sn35.12:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, sights of the past and future are not-self,

sn35.12:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītesu rūpesu anapekkho hoti;

sn35.12:1.5.pli: paccuppannānaṃ rūpānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn35.12:1.12.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītesu dhammesu anapekkho hoti;

sn35.12:1.14.pli: paccuppannānaṃ dhammānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.
